title: About Activity Plugin
synopsis: The Activity plugin lists pages in your neighborhood. It expand as your neighborhood grows. Page names used on multiple sites are grouped together with the most current site listed first. Read [[More About Activity Plugin]].

title: Access to Nature
synopsis: Understanding our relationship to nature (in the city) is a long and detailed social history of the development of cities and of local government.

title: Action Research
synopsis: Action research takes the position that the researcher is part of the research. It is connected to the epistemological claim that knowledge is not discovered but created.

title: Ada Lovelace
synopsis: Augusta Ada King-Noel, Countess of Lovelace (née Byron; 10 December 1815 – 27 November 1852) was an English mathematician and writer, chiefly known for her work on [[Charles Babbage]]'s proposed mechanical general-purpose computer, the Analytical Engine. She was the first to recognise that the machine had applications beyond pure calculation, and created the first algorithm intended to be carried out by such a machine. As a result, she is often regarded as the first to recognise the full potential of a "computing machine" and the first computer programme

title: Anomie
synopsis: Anomie is a "condition in which society provides little moral guidance to individuals". It is the breakdown of social bonds between an individual and the community, e.g., under unruly scenarios resulting in fragmentation of social identity and rejection of self-regulatory values. It was popularized by French sociologist Émile Durkheim in his influential book Suicide (1897). Durkheim never uses the term normlessness; rather, he describes anomie as "derangement", and "an insatiable will". Durkheim used the term "the malady of the infinite" because desire w

title: Birkenhead Park
synopsis: Birkenhead Park is a public park in the centre of Birkenhead, in the Metropolitan Borough of Wirral, in Merseyside, England. It was designed by [[Joseph Paxton]] and opened on 5 April 1847. It is generally acknowledged as the first publicly funded civic park in the world. Paxton had earlier designed Princes Park, Liverpool, a private development - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birkenhead_Park wikipedia]

title: Boolean Search Compositor
synopsis: An investigation into the cognition of search through an interface using the physical world.

title: Capability Approach
synopsis: The [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capability_approach capability approach] (also referred to as the capabilities approach) is an economic theory conceived in the 1980s as an alternative approach to welfare economics. In this approach, [[Amartya Sen]] brings together a range of ideas that were previously excluded from (or inadequately formulated in) traditional approaches to the economics of welfare. The core focus of the capability approach is on what individuals are able to do (i.e., capable of).

title: Deep Time
synopsis: Deep time is the concept of geologic time. The modern philosophical concept was developed in the 18th century by Scottish geologist James Hutton (1726–1797). The age of the Earth has been determined to be, after a long and complex history of developments, around 4.55 billion years - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_time wikipedia]

title: Define the Scope
synopsis: A project works best when its goals are clearly stated so that participants can join with realistic expectations of what they are working towards. Using the 'Why, How and What' formula from Simon Sinek's book '[[Start with Why]]' is great way to pack a vision statement.

title: Dietrich Bonhoeffer

title: Doomsday Clock
synopsis: The Doomsday Clock is a symbol which represents the likelihood of a man-made global catastrophe. Maintained since 1947 by the members of the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists' Science and Security Board, the clock represents an analogy for the threat of global nuclear war. Since 2007, it has also reflected climate change and new developments in the life sciences and technology that could inflict irrevocable harm to humanity - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doomsday_Clock wikipedia]

title: E. O. Wilson
synopsis: Known to many as the founding father of socio-biology, E O Wilson is a big hitter in the world of evolutionary theory. But, recently he's criticised what's popularly known as The Selfish Gene theory of evolution that he once worked so hard to promote (and that now underpins the mainstream view on evolution).

title: Ecocide
synopsis: Ecocide is any harm caused to the [[Ecosystem]] and therfore a harm to all. The term is not yet in common currency because the historic development of law was not ecosystem aware. By focusing on harm to person, property or state it has traditionally struggled to categorise nature.

title: Ecological Footprint
synopsis: The ecological footprint measures human demand on nature, i.e., the quantity of nature it takes to support people or an economy. It tracks this demand through an ecological accounting system. The accounts contrast the biologically productive area people use for their consumption to the biologically productive area available within a region or the world (biocapacity - the productive area that can regenerate what people demand from nature). In short, it is a measure of human impact on Earth's ecosystem and reveals the dependence of the human economy on nat

title: Ecological Succession
synopsis: Ecological succession is the process of change in the species structure of an ecological community over time. The time scale can be decades (for example, after a wildfire), or even millions of years after a mass extinction - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_succession wikipedia]

title: Ecosystem
synopsis: The term "ecosystem" was first used in 1935 in a publication by British ecologist [[Arthur Tansley]].

title: Ecotherapy
synopsis: Ecotherapy is the broader umbrella term for a range of activity of which horticultural therapy is part.

title: Eleanor Marx
synopsis: Eleanor Marx lived the last years of her life in Sydenham. She was the first translator of [[Madame Bovary]] into English. Like Emma Bovary she committed suicide by taking poison. She was pronounced dead by [[Ernest Shackleton]]'s father Henry who lived round the corner and was the local doctor.

title: EOS
synopsis: 'The blockchain operating system for commercial scale decentralized applications.'

title: Epistemic Sensors
synopsis: By collecting (applicable) data and metrics from the conference, an algorithm could diagnose progress toward predefined goals.

title: Event Composer

title: Facilitation

title: FEAST Activity
synopsis: This form of writing and co-creation that we explore is new. It is an unusual and new way to collaborate, one which encourages us to share our early thoughts as we see them pass from hand to hand. This process we have called before [[Writing With Strangers]].

title: Finsbury Park
synopsis: Finsbury Park is a public park in the ward of the London neighbourhood of Harringay. It is in the area formerly covered by the historic parish of Hornsey, succeeded by the Municipal Borough of Hornsey - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finsbury_Park wikipedia]

title: Found Landscape
synopsis: There is a tradition of 'found art' or 'objet trouve' which enables the presentation of 'everyday' objects in a fine art context.

title: Fractal Narrative
synopsis: Federated Wiki is a superb example of what I call a 'Fractal Narrative', something hypermedia like which could only ever be told deeply (immersively) by moving into and out from various scales, centres or proximities.

title: Future Studies
synopsis: Future studies is an emerging academic discipline to rigorously examine claims about the future. It is epistemological in that it centralises the arguments about what is knowable, such as sorting through the discourse to separate 'scientific analysis' from general criticism. This is a sorting process of discerning hard and soft science, to give academic rigour to the domain. It makes the distinctions between what is possible, what is probable and what is desirable.

title: Gamification
synopsis: Gamification is the process of taking a task or series of tasks and assigning them elements of play which extend the experience from purposeful to recreational.

title: General Purpose Technology
synopsis: General-purpose technologies (GPTs) are technologies that can affect an entire economy (usually at a national or global level),,. GPTs have the potential to drastically alter societies through their impact on pre-existing economic and social structures. Examples include the steam engine, railroad, interchangeable parts, electricity, electronics, material handling, mechanization, control theory (automation), the automobile, the computer, the Internet, medicine and the blockchain - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_purpose_technology wikipedia]

title: George Vulliamy
synopsis: George John Vulliamy (1817–1886)

title: Graph Zooming
synopsis: [[Andrew Orford]] coined this term to describe the active moving inward or into (and outward or out of) a fractal like graph used in exploring an argument or [[Fractal Narrative]].

title: Habitus
synopsis: Habitus is the name Pierre Bourdieu used to describe the dispositional state which is enacted daily by anyone and everyone.

title: Halo
synopsis: A wiki page is rendered with a colored border when that page has been retrieved from other than the origin site. A hover over the page flag may explain details.

title: Hans-Georg Gadamer
synopsis: Hans-Georg Gadamer (German: [ˈɡaːdamɐ]; February 11, 1900 – March 13, 2002) was a German philosopher of the continental tradition, best known for his 1960 magnum opus Truth and Method (Wahrheit und Methode) on hermeneutics. He was a Protestant Christian - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hans-Georg_Gadamer wikipedia]

title: Heutagogy
synopsis: Heutagogy is the study and practice of self-determined learning. Students are not recipients of teaching, but participants in it.

It is now a leading educational resource for the study of ethnography and natural history. Its development has also featured in an emerging academic discipline of 'critical museology'.

title: I-Space
synopsis: The I-Space framework (3 axes model) was developed by [[Max Boisot]] to illustrate 3 dimensions of knowledge:

title: Janusz Korczak
synopsis: Janusz Korczak is well known in his native Poland as an author of childrens books. He visited [[Louise House]] industrial girls home in Forest Hill to investigate enlightened approaches to education and welfare. He was impressed by his visit and wrote up notes which show the development of his ideas regarding early education methods. He focused on the social and agential aspect of child development.

title: Joseph Cambpell
synopsis: Joseph Campbell is an anthropologist of folklore systems who theorised that most stories invoke archetypal characters whose journey is an inner quest toward self-actualisation. He detailed how that journey was challenged or thwarted by psychic battles between the different motivational needs of the story characters.

title: Joseph Paxton
synopsis: Sir Joseph Paxton (3 August 1803 – 8 June 1865) was an English gardener, architect and Member of Parliament, best known for designing the Crystal Palace, and for cultivating the Cavendish banana, the most consumed banana in the Western world - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Paxton wikipedia]

title: Jürgen Habermas
synopsis: Jürgen Habermas ( or ; German: [ˈjʏrɡn̩ ˈhaːbɐmaːs]; born 18 June 1929) is a German sociologist and philosopher in the tradition of critical theory and pragmatism. He is perhaps best known for his theories on communicative rationality and the public sphere. In 2014, Prospect readers chose Habermas as one of their favourites among the "world's leading thinkers." - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J%C3%BCrgen_Habermas wikipedia]

title: Kairos
synopsis: Kairos (καιρός) is an Ancient Greek word meaning the right, critical, or opportune moment. The ancient Greeks had two words for time: chronos (χρόνος) and kairos. While the former refers to chronological or sequential time, the latter signifies a proper or opportune time for action. What is happening when referring to kairos depends on who is using the word. While chronos is quantitative, kairos has a qualitative, permanent nature. Kairos also means weather in Modern Greek. The plural, καιροί (kairoi (Ancient and Modern Greek)) means the times - [https:/

synopsis: In economics, Kondratiev waves (also called supercycles, great surges, long waves, K-waves or the long economic cycle) are hypothesized cycle-like phenomena in the modern world economy - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kondratiev_wave wikipedia]

title: Long Now Foundation
synopsis: The Long Now Foundation, established in 1996, is a public, non-profit organization based in San Francisco that seeks to become the seed of a very long-term cultural institution. It aims to provide a counterpoint to what it views as today's "faster/cheaper" mindset and to promote "slower/better" thinking. The Long Now Foundation hopes to "creatively foster responsibility" in the framework of the next 10,000 years. In a manner somewhat similar to the Holocene calendar, the foundation uses 5-digit dates to address the Year 10,000 problem (e.g., by writing "

title: Louise Michel
synopsis: Louise Michel stayed in Albion Villas Rd at the household of her companion's father. This makes her the nearest historic figure to what is now [[Albion Millennium Green]]. Louise Michel is a legend in France and she lived a very long and full life.

title: Lt Col J J Sexby
synopsis: John James Sexby was Superintendent of Parks and Gardens for the London County Council.  He wrote Municipal Parks, Gardens and Open Spaces of London (1898).

title: Machine Learning
synopsis: Machine Learning in [[Artificial Intelligence]] specifically focuses on computers getting better at recognising data without being explicitly programmed exactly how to.

title: Madame Bovary
synopsis: Afterwards she would wander through the room exploring it. She would open draws, look at herself in his shaving mirror. Often times, she would place his pipe between her teeth, the one he kept on his night table among the lemons, the lumps of sugar, and the jug of water. It took them a good quarter of an hour to say goodbye.

title: Margret Archer
synopsis: The legendary doyenne of sociology who is concerned with the conceptual frameworks for understanding the structure/agency debate.

title: Mathis Wackernagel
synopsis: Mathis Wackernagel is a Swiss-born sustainability advocate. He is President of Global Footprint Network, an international sustainability think tank with offices in Oakland, California; Brussels, Belgium, and Geneva, Switzerland. The think-tank is a non-profit that focuses on developing and promoting metrics for sustainability - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathis_Wackernagel wikipedia]

title: Max Boisot
synopsis: Max Boisot (11 November 1943 – 7 September 2011) was a management (and [[Knowledge Management]]) theorist whose work at [[CERN]] led him to ask how such a decentralised science project (with so many scientists) could successfully exist. This question led him to speculate that various forms of information transmission 'travelled' in differing form factors. He called this theory [[I-Space]].

synopsis: Obuchenie is the Russian word which does not translate in English in an equivalent sense, but roughly speaking it means both teaching and learning. title: Peter Collinson
synopsis: Peter Collinson (January 1694 – 11 August 1768) was a Fellow of the Royal Society, an avid gardener, and the middleman for an international exchange of scientific ideas in mid-18th century London. He is best known for his horticultural friendship with John Bartram and his correspondence with [[Benjamin Franklin]].

title: Pierre Bourdieu
synopsis: Pierre Bourdieu (1 August 1930 – 23 January 2002) was an influential sociologist who examined the role of 'everyday life' as being at the heart of political power. He produced a vast body of work and is one of the most cited sociologists of all time. His contributions are too numerous to detail in a brief survey so his work on [[Habitus]] is referred to as a key concept and introduction.

title: Pinterest
synopsis: A page with 0 items.

title: Place
synopsis: This is where I store topics on place based investigation.

title: Pod Club
synopsis: Pod Club is an [[Asynchronous Salon]] format to explore speech based journalism and media literacy within the [[Public Sphere]].

title: Printing Press
synopsis: The development of the printing press, typesetting and then full colour lithography is a record of technological progress with specific social and political resonance.

title: Professor Henry Higgins
synopsis: Henry Higgins in the play and film Pygmalion changes the life of Eliza through coaching her speech. In so doing the relationship between teacher and student is explored. The setting for the professional activity of Higgins is a private clinic in the Harley Street area of London. This is the area associated with specialist medicine which developed in an era before the National Health Service.

title: Project Bovary
synopsis: The original idea was to create a promenade performance (reading excerpts from Madame Bovary) while we walk from [[St.Bartholomew's Church]], Sydenham (the resting place of [[Robert Harrild]], past [[Eleanor Marx]] and through Sydenham's conservation area (once the canal's reservoir) to Round Hill house, home of Robert Harrild, and St.Antholin's Spire.

title: Psychogeography of Sydenham
synopsis: As a general rule, place names in London start out as designations which cover a large area. They are then additionally peppered with points such as the names of farms, wells, mills and taverns. Through the process of densification, smaller areas become nominalised until the original name covers a much smaller area. For instance, an area once bordering Sydenham, [[Penge Common]] and [[South Norwood]] is now called [[Crystal Palace]] after the entertainment complex was transferred to Sydenham from Hyde Park. title: Research Portfolio
synopsis: I locate people, projects and case studies which are apt material for discursive investigations into the impact of innovation. This confluence of [[Future Studies]] themed content is then ranked for its applicability to form the basis of discussion. I then organise the information into a form factor which is suitable to be utilised within a facilitated discourse.

title: Richard Jefferies
synopsis: Richard Jefferies the pioneering nature writer is remembered in Sydenham by a plaque on his uncle and aunt's house where he often stayed. This house is the nearest venue to [[Albion Millennium Green]] with a historic plaque.

title: Robert Harrild
synopsis: Robert Harrild was a successful printer whose company Harrild & Sons licensed the design for the [[Albion Press]] to manufacture them. The head London office was in Farringdon Road which is now a bar which remembers the company name.

title: Salus populi suprema lex esto
synopsis: Salus populi suprema lex esto (Latin: "The health (welfare, good, salvation, felicity) of the people should be the supreme law", "Let the good (or safety) of the people be the supreme (or highest) law", or "The welfare of the people shall be the supreme law") is a maxim or principle found in Cicero's De Legibus (book III, part III, sub. VIII) - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salus_populi_suprema_lex_esto wikipedia]

title: Salutogenesis
synopsis: It means the origin or cause of health, so it is the opposite of pathogenesis (the origin of disease). [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salutogenesis wikipedia]

title: Situated Green Project
synopsis: Within environmentalism, some green projects are necessarily confined to a tightly defined geographical area, such as conservation of a habitat. At the other extreme are projects which address issues which are universal. A campaign to address the [[Behaviour Change]] necessary for [[Clean Air]] would be relevant in any area of the world.

title: Social Library
synopsis: This entry primarily refers to the use of the word 'library' as an abstract noun, like the word network. This does not exclude the term library also referring to a tangible place.

title: Southwark Park
synopsis: Southwark Park is located in Rotherhithe, in central South East London, and is managed by the London Borough of Southwark. It first opened in 1869 by the Metropolitan Board of Works as one of its first parks. It was designed by [[Alexander McKenzie]] and covers 63 acres (250,000 m2). It takes its name from being in what was the old Parliamentary constituency of Southwark at the time of its opening - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southwark_Park wikipedia]

title: St.Antholin
synopsis: Saint Antholin or St. Anthony the Great (of the desert) is the prototype hermit monk whom is revered as the father of monasticism.

title: St.Antholin's Spire
synopsis: [[St.Antholin]]'s Church in Watling Street / Budge Row stood from at least 1119 and was rebuilt several times. It remained until 1875 when it was demolished for the creation of Great Queen Street. The archaeological importance of its location was only to be revealed after the Second World War.

title: Tetrad Of Media Effects
synopsis: Generally speaking, a tetrad is any set of four things. In Laws of Media (1988) and The Global Village (1989), published posthumously, Marshall McLuhan summarized his ideas about media in a concise tetrad of media effects. The tetrad is a means of examining the effects on society of any technology/medium (put another way: a means of explaining the social processes underlying the adoption of a technology/medium) by dividing its effects into four categories and displaying them simultaneously. McLuhan designed the tetrad as a pedagogical tool, phrasing his

synopsis: The Demon-Haunted World: Science as a Candle in the Dark is a 1995 book by astrophysicist Carl Sagan, in which the author aims to explain the scientific method to laypeople, and to encourage people to learn critical and skeptical thinking.

title: Transit of Venus
synopsis: A transit of Venus across the Sun takes place when the planet Venus passes directly between the Sun and a superior planet, becoming visible against (and hence obscuring a small portion of) the solar disk. During a transit, Venus can be seen from Earth as a small black disk moving across the face of the Sun. The duration of such transits is usually several hours (the transit of 2012 lasted 6 hours and 40 minutes). A transit is similar to a solar eclipse by the Moon. While the diameter of Venus is more than three times that of the Moon, Venus appears small

title: Xylem and Phloem
synopsis: The fundamental unidirectional vs. bidirectional differences in plant vascularity are apt metaphors for the movement constraints within any life or informational system.

title: Yochai Benkler
synopsis: Benkler's 2006 book [[The Wealth of Networks]] describes the impact on society of new ways to work. In this presentation to the World Economic Forum he refers to the work of [[Karl Polanyi]] and his 1944 book: The Great Transformation. It is a critique of the so called shared economy or on-demand economy which highlights the threats to social solidarity.

title: Zbigniew Brzezinski
synopsis: Zbigniew Kazimierz "Zbig" Brzezinski (; Polish: [ˈzbʲiɡɲɛf kaˈʑimʲɛʐ bʐɛˈʑiɲskʲi] ( listen); March 28, 1928 – May 26, 2017) was a Polish-American diplomat and political scientist. He served as a counselor to President Lyndon B. Johnson from 1966 to 1968 and was President Jimmy Carter's National Security Advisor from 1977 to 1981. Brzezinski belonged to the realist school of international relations, standing in the geopolitical tradition of Halford Mackinder and Nicholas J. Spykman - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zbigniew_Brzezinski wikipedia]
